docs.snippet: The North American Soccer League, which operated with 24 franchises two years ago, will open its 16th season on Saturday with 14 teams.  The reduction had been supported by the league's more established teams, especially influential franchises such...
docs.lead_paragraph: The North American Soccer League, which operated with 24 franchises two years ago, will open its 16th season on Saturday with 14 teams. The reduction had been supported by the league's more established teams, especially influential franchises such as the Cosmos, Chicago and Seattle. They thought that expansion from 18 to 24 teams in 1978 was a mistake. In fact, spokesmen for the Cosmos, Chicago and Seattle had said at a league meeting in Chicago two years ago that they would have liked to see the league reduced to 12 franchises, mostly by way of mergers. Dallas has been the only franchise that merged, however, joining forces with Tampa Bay. Six others have folded since last season and they were preceded by the demise of three others before last season. Atlanta, Calgary, California, Los Angeles, Minnesota and Washington are the franchises that have folded since last season. Of the six, Minnesota's loss was the only shocking development.

headline.main: WITH FEWER TEAMS, THE GOAL IS BALANCE

docs.lead_paragraph: Announcement has been made by Seta York McCormick of Shreveport, La., and Raymond Browning Gill Jr. of Huntsville, Ala., of the engagement of their daughter, Lisa York Gill, to Walter Evans Gray, son of Frank Biddle Gray of Montevideo, Uruguay, and Blanche Fleming Gray of Memphis. A May wedding is planned.

headline.main: Lisa York Gill Engaged to Walter Gray

docs.snippet: Several thousand Argentine troops overcame 84 British marines today and seized the Falkland Islands in the South Atlantic.   The Argentine junta announced that army, navy and air force units captured the British-held Falklands, 250 miles off the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Several thousand Argentine troops overcame 84 British marines today and seized the Falkland Islands in the South Atlantic. The Argentine junta announced that army, navy and air force units captured the British-held Falklands, 250 miles off the southeastern tip of Argentina, and the South Georgia and South Sandwich Islands, British dependencies to the east. President Reagan sought to persuade the head of the junta to call off the invasion, but his 50-minute telephone call was in vain. (Page 6.)

docs.snippet: Foreign Minister Nicanor Costa Mendez of Argentina will address the permanent council of the Organization of American States here on Monday.   An announcement said the current chairman, Francisco Bustillo of Uruguay, had scheduled the meeting at...
docs.lead_paragraph: Foreign Minister Nicanor Costa Mendez of Argentina will address the permanent council of the Organization of American States here on Monday. An announcement said the current chairman, Francisco Bustillo of Uruguay, had scheduled the meeting at Argentina's request.

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Argentina said today that it would ''not retreat'' from its seizure of the Falkland Islands from Britain.  The Government also announced that it was breaking relations with Britain and ordered British diplomats to leave Argentina by next Thursday, in...
docs.lead_paragraph: Argentina said today that it would ''not retreat'' from its seizure of the Falkland Islands from Britain. The Government also announced that it was breaking relations with Britain and ordered British diplomats to leave Argentina by next Thursday, in response to a similar British move Friday. The Economics Ministry announced tonight that it had frozen all British assets in Argentina, hours after London said it would freeze Argentina's assets in Britain. The British Governor of the islands, Rex Hunt, his family and the contingent of about 80 British marines that had been on the island arrived in Montevideo, Uruguay, on an Argentine Air Force C-130 transport plane. They are scheduled to go to Britain Sunday.

headline.main: ARGENTINA SAYS IT WILL 'NOT RETREAT' AND BREAKS RELATIONS WITH BRITAIN

byline.original: By EDWARD SCHUMACHER, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, speaking during the first weekend session of Parliament since the Suez crisis of 1956, said today that the Falkland Islands ''remain British territory'' and ordered a large naval task force to the South Atlantic.  ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, speaking during the first weekend session of Parliament since the Suez crisis of 1956, said today that the Falkland Islands ''remain British territory'' and ordered a large naval task force to the South Atlantic. In addition, Mrs. Thatcher announced that Argentina's financial assets in Britain would be frozen and other economic sanctions would be imposed. In Buenos Aires, the military Government said it would ''not retreat'' from its seizure of the islands. It broke diplomatic relations with Britain, in response to a similar move by London on Friday, and froze British assets in Argentina. (Page 18.)

headline.main: LONDON ORDERING 35-SHIP TASK FORCE TO THE FALKLANDS

byline.original: By STEVEN RATTNER, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: The Cosmos scored another impressive victory against a reputable foreign opponent by defeating the national team of Peru, 5-1, today at Giants Stadium.   The teams rewarded a crowd of 37,408, which braved 34-degree weather and winds gusting to 40...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Cosmos scored another impressive victory against a reputable foreign opponent by defeating the national team of Peru, 5-1, today at Giants Stadium. The teams rewarded a crowd of 37,408, which braved 34-degree weather and winds gusting to 40 miles, with a performance typical of top international matches. In a flag-waving atmosphere, the play at times was outstanding, but it was also rough.

headline.main: COSMOS BEAT PERU IN ROUGH GAME, 5-1

byline.original: By ALEX YANNIS, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Argentina's large and influential British community is growing increasingly uneasy as the crisis over the Falkland Islands continues.   The British naval attache's home was bombed Monday. There were no injuries, but it was one of a small but growing...
docs.lead_paragraph: Argentina's large and influential British community is growing increasingly uneasy as the crisis over the Falkland Islands continues. The British naval attache's home was bombed Monday. There were no injuries, but it was one of a small but growing number of anti-British incidents, including the breaking of windows in British schools, occasional hostility in the streets and telephone threats against British institutions. The delivery of the English-language Buenos Aires Herald was suspended Wednesday by the distributors' union ''for its defense of British interests,'' according to a union statement.

headline.main: BIG BRITISH COMMUNITY IN ARGENTINA IS UNEASY

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: AFTER attending a recent meeting of Latin American writers in Puerto Rico, Jorge Amado stopped in New York to visit his American publishers and, with his wife, Zelia, to pay a call on Alfred A.  Knopf. It was a nostalgic reunion, because Mr. Knopf,...
docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER attending a recent meeting of Latin American writers in Puerto Rico, Jorge Amado stopped in New York to visit his American publishers and, with his wife, Zelia, to pay a call on Alfred A. Knopf. It was a nostalgic reunion, because Mr. Knopf, the 89-year-old founder of the publishing house that bears his name, first brought the Brazilian writer to the attention of readers in the United States in 1945 by publishing ''The Violent Land,'' a sparse, stark novel about the bloody struggle over Brazil's cocoa lands. Knopf later published many other Amado novels, including the rollicking ''Gabriela, Clove and Cinnamon,'' ''Dona Flor and Her Two Husbands'' (the basis for a Brazilian movie and of ''Sarava,'' the 1979 Broadway musical) and ''Shepherds of the Night.''

headline.main: PUBLISHING: AMADO PAYS KNOPF A NOSTALGIC VISIT

docs.snippet: Argentina's Foreign Minister said today that ''the danger of war with Britain is fading.'' Speaking at the airport upon returning from Washington, the Minister, Nicanor Costa Mendez, said he was ''very optimistic'' about the chances of a peaceful...
docs.lead_paragraph: Argentina's Foreign Minister said today that ''the danger of war with Britain is fading.'' Speaking at the airport upon returning from Washington, the Minister, Nicanor Costa Mendez, said he was ''very optimistic'' about the chances of a peaceful settlement of the crisis with Britain over Argentina's seizure of the the Falkland Islands, a British colony. Mr. Costa Mendez said he based his optimism on the diplomatic effort begun today by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., who flew to London to explore the possibilities of negotiations. The Secretary is due here after his London mission is completed.

byline.original: By EDWARD SCHUMACHER, Special to the New York Times
